article: When I was a child, I had an old neighbour named Dr. Gibbs. He didn t look like any other doctor I ve ever known. He never _ at us for playing in his yard. I remembered him as a kind and _ person When Dr. Gibbs didn t work, he planted trees. His house covered an area of ten acres, and his life s goal was to make it _ . He had some interesting _ concerning planting. He belonged to the No pains, no gains _ of plant growing. He never watered his new trees. Once I asked _ , he said, Watering plants will spoil them, and if you water them, each successive tree _ will grow weaker and weaker. So you have to make things _ for them and weed out the weak ones. So he never watered his trees. He would _ a pine, and instead of _ it every morning, he beat it with a rolled-up newspaper. I _ him why he did so, and he said it was to get the tree s _ . I planted a couple of trees a few _ ago. I carried water to them for a solid summer, sprayed them and prayed over them. Two years of careful tending has _ in trees that expect to be _ to hand and foot. Whenever a cold wind blows in, they tremble their branches. Dr. Gibbs passed away a _ of years after I left home. Now and then, I walked by his house and looked at the trees. They re _ now, big and healthy. Funny things about Dr. Gibbs trees. Hardship and difficulty seemed to benefit them _ comfort and ease never could. Life is tough, whether we want _ to be or not. Too many times we pray for ease, but that s a prayer seldom met. What we need to do is to pray for _ that reach deep into the earth, so when the rains fall and the winds blow, we won t be swept away.
